H0.text: Camouflage is the development of the viceroy butterfly’s pattern to resemble the monarch butterfly, which deters many birds from eating it because monarch butterflies contain a substance that makes the birds sick.

H1.text: Coloration is the development of the viceroy butterfly’s pattern that mimics the monarch butterfly, deterring birds by resembling a toxic species.

H2.text: Diversity is the example of the development of the viceroy butterfly’s pattern to resemble that of the toxic monarch butterfly, a strategy that deters birds that avoid eating monarchs because they contain a substance that makes the birds sick.

H3.text: Mimicry is the evolution of the viceroy butterfly’s coloration pattern to resemble the toxic monarch butterfly, a strategy that deters birds from eating the viceroy because monarchs contain a substance that makes birds sick.

A4.text: Monarchs share the defense of noxious taste with the similar-appearing viceroy butterfly in what is perhaps one of the most well-known examples of mimicry.
